Award.AwardTitle: Nuclear Structure, Mesoscopic Physics and Double Beta Decay
Award.AbstractNarration:
Research topics covered by this award include (i) development of new analytical and computational tools for the description of nuclear structure, especially for the nuclei far from stability; (ii) detailed consideration of specific new nuclear phenomena encountered with experimental advances into virgin territory of unstable nuclei; (iii) modeling of structural and dynamical aspects of nuclear processes of astrophysical interest; (iv) understanding nuclear matrix elements related to fundamental symmetries and double-beta decay and (v) development of the unified description of structure and reactions in open and marginally stable mesoscopic systems, including nuclear reactions, conductance fluctuations and quantum transport.

We will train graduate students who are attracted to the activities in our group and to the number one ranked graduate school in nuclear physics in the US. Our proposed research relates to broad questions in science including: What are the limits of nuclear stability? How did the chemical evolution of the Universe proceed? How do nuclear properties emerge from the underlying nucleon-nucleon interactions? How can we use nuclear data to understand fundamental symmetries and neutrino properties? How does order coexist with chaos and complexity in quantum mesoscopic systems? The suggested program is expected to have appreciable impact on developments in the field of nuclear theory, nuclear astrophysics and the general field of mesoscopic physics. Many of the projects are connected to the experimental programs at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) and other laboratories. Projects are also closely coupled with the Joint Institute for Nuclear Astrophysics (JINA).

Our work on "Nuclear Structure, Mesoscopic Physics and Double Beta Decay'' covered a number of  important topics of modern nuclear physics that relate to many-body quantum physics.
 
We have witness a Renaissance of nuclear science. Several factors  triggered this development.  We currently know about 300 stable nuclear isotopes, together with some properties of about 3000 unstable isotopes. Nuclei far from stability are studied at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) at Michigan State University (MSU) and other laboratories. Our group collaborated with experimentalists at the NSCL to guide the ideas for experiments and to understand the significance of the results obtained. Theory has shown that there about 3000 more isotopes in nature that are unknown. Many of these will be made and studied at the new  Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB) under construction at MSU.  We collaborated on the proposals for FRIB.

Unstable nuclei are generated in various processes occurring in the cosmos. Nuclear decays and reactions determine the abundance of different chemical elements in the Universe. Nuclear processes are responsible for the stellar evolution and the structure of stars. Our group contributed to many aspects of this by creating new models and results
for reaction rates, level densities, and the nuclear equation of state. We  collaborate with the  Joint Institute for Nuclear Astrophysics (JINA) at MSU.

Nuclear processes shed light on fundamental properties of elementary particles and their interactions. For example, the violation of the symmetry with respect to the inversion of coordinates was predicted and experimentally discovered in weak nuclear transformations. New questions that relate to nuclear properties and their theoretical understanding include; is the neutrino its own anti-particle (a Majorana fermion)?,  what is the mass of the neutrino?, what is nature dark matter?, and, does the weak interaction violate time-reversal symmetry?  The neutrino properties can be studied in the rare process of the  neutrinoless double beta decay when two neutrons decay into two protons without the emission of two neutrinos. Many experiments are being proposed to study this type of decay.  Our group made many contributions to the  nuclear theory needed to evaluate the decay probability, and to guide these extremely delicate experiments.

Our theoretical and computational work covered all these directions. Our most advanced computational code, NuShellX, allows one to do calculations of nuclear structure in spaces with dimensions up to about one billion. We not only performed many detailed calculations of nuclear structure with this code in collaboration with nuclear experimentalists,  but have made the code available  for the broad nuclear community. Working with nuclei away from stability, we need to explicitly account for the continuum states (channels of nuclear decay). For this purpose we have developed the Continuum shell model' that generalizes the classical shell-model of a closed system.

The quantitative description of astrophysical reactions is impossible without detailed nuclear calculations. One important element for such studies and general evaluation of the reaction network in cosmos is the knowledge of number of states (level density) for a given nucleus at a given excitation energy. We have developed a new algorithm for finding this level density for various classes of nuclear states. This computational scheme is based on statistical properties of mesoscopic systems, and allows one to obtain results without full solution of the quantum many-body problem.
